title: 111_hr5676
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Omnibus Right to Equitable Means of Ensuring Damages for Injuries are Efficiently Secured Act of 2010", also known as the "REMEDIES Act". The Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico caused the largest environmental disaster in US history, resulting in 11 deaths, injuries, wildlife damage, and economic losses in Gulf Coast communities. Over 80 million gallons of oil leaked into the Gulf, causing tens of billions of dollars in damage. Many victims may not receive full compensation under current law. The Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico led to the largest environmental disaster in US history, causing 11 deaths, injuries, wildlife damage, and economic losses in Gulf Coast communities. Victims are struggling to receive full compensation due to lax permitting standards and inadequate compensation apparatus set up by BP plc. The Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico caused the largest environmental disaster in US history, resulting in 11 deaths, injuries, wildlife damage, and economic losses in Gulf Coast communities. Victims are facing challenges in receiving full compensation due to lax permitting standards and inadequate compensation apparatus set up by BP plc. SEC. 3 addresses liability under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990. Increase in liability limitations under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990: 
- Liability limits have been raised significantly, such as from $3,000 to $6,000 for certain cases.
- This amendment aims to address challenges faced by victims of environmental disasters like the Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is being amended to increase liability limits significantly, with changes like raising the limit from $75,000,000 to $150,000,000. Additionally, a new provision for excess liability is introduced, allowing the President to pay any unrecoverable liability from a responsible party, up to $10,300,000,000 from the Trust Fund for any incident. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to increase liability limits, with a new provision allowing the President to pay up to $10,300,000,000 from the Trust Fund for any incident. This section is not retroactive. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO OIL SPILL LIABILITY TRUST FUND. Increase in Size of the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund from $2 billion to $10 billion, increase in per-incident cleanup cap from $1 billion to $10 billion, increase in tax rates from 8 cents to 30 cents and from 9 cents to 40 cents, and repeal of sunset of Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund financing rate. The amendments to the tax code include removing certain paragraphs, updating expenditures from the Trust Fund, and specifying the effective date of the changes. The amendments will not have a retroactive effect. SEC. 5. AMENDMENT TO JONES ACT. Section 30104 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to replace "seamen" with "covered maritime employees" and define a covered maritime employee as a seaman or an individual employed on an offshore facility. The amendment also expands the definition of who can file a claim for injury or death to include spouses, parents, children, siblings, dependent relatives, or any person whose act or omission caused the injury or death. The amendment to section 30104 of title 46, United States Code, expands the definition of covered maritime employees to include individuals employed on an offshore facility or a mobile offshore drilling unit. The chapter analysis in title 46 is also amended to reflect this change. SEC. 6 amends the Death on the High Seas Act to cover personal injury or death of covered maritime employees. The Death on the High Seas Act is amended to include compensation for nonpecuniary loss, such as pain and suffering, and may include punitive damages for gross negligence or willful misconduct. Nonpecuniary loss is defined as loss of care, comfort, and companionship. The Death on the High Seas Act is amended to include compensation for nonpecuniary loss, such as pain and suffering, and may include punitive damages for gross negligence or willful misconduct. A restriction on recovery by noncitizen and nonresident alien workers for incidents arising during international voyages of foreign vessels is also introduced. The Death on the High Seas Act is amended to allow compensation for nonpecuniary loss and punitive damages for gross negligence or willful misconduct. A restriction is introduced for noncitizen and nonresident alien workers seeking remedies for incidents on international voyages of foreign vessels. SEC. 7. REQUIREMENT FOR REDUNDANCY IN RESPONSE PLANS. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require response plans to include redundancies for failed actions and be vetted by impartial experts. Additionally, introduces a new section in the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act mandating response plans for drilling permits. SEC. 8. SUSPENSION OF DRILLING PERMIT FOR SAFETY VIOLATIONS. Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to suspend drilling permits for 5 or more safety violations within a 1-year period. SEC. 9. PROCESSING OF CLAIMS BY RESPONSIBLE PARTIES. Amends the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 to require responsible parties to process claims for loss of income by considering categories of business, making determinations based on unique practices, and treating fishermen separately. SEC. 10. CLASS ACTION FAIRNESS ACT. Amends Title 28, United States Code to clarify that class actions do not include actions brought by a State or subdivision on behalf of its citizens. SEC. 11. MULTI-PARTY LITIGATION. SEC. 11. MULTI-PARTY LITIGATION. Amends Section 1407 of title 28, United States Code to exclude certain actions from its application. SEC. 12. INDEPENDENT CLAIMS SYSTEM. SEC. 12. The Secretary of Homeland Security can require liable entities under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 to establish an independent claims system for all related claims, categorizing claimants and setting proof guidelines. The President will establish an emergency oil spill coordination team, including key officials from various government agencies, to respond to oil spills in the United States. Additionally, a research and development team will be established. The President will appoint a research and development team to focus on new technologies for preventing oil spills, particularly in deep water drilling. The oil industry will establish a $1 billion fund for research on oil spill recovery. The team will consist of experts from government, industry, research, and academia. Additionally, the Secretary of Homeland Security will provide extensive PTSD counseling for victims of major oil spill disasters. A panel of experts will assess the long-term environmental impacts of the Gulf oil spill. The EPA Administrator will establish a panel of experts to evaluate the long-term environmental impacts of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The President will issue regulations to limit liability under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, similar to the Price-Anderson Act. The Act will take effect on April 15, 2010.
